WRITING.TITLE: Doom won't launch after switching to vulkan
WRITING.TEXT:
I've searched a bunch of forums and here are the things I tried:
* updated drivers * typed +r_renderAPI-1 into launch options on steam * typed +r_renderAPI-0 into launch options * tried launching DOOMx64.exe manually * tried launching DOOMx64vk.exe manually
When I tried launching DOOMx64vk.exe manually, it says I'm missing vulkan-1.dll
I've seen suggestions on forums to make changes to doomconfig.local, but that file isn't there.
It worked when I was running on openGL but since I changed it, I can't get it to run at all.
Haven't played Fo4 in probably 4-5 months, but I might just start up a new game to make some of my own!

I didn't look into statistics, but if thats true that it does prevent smoking, I'd still be cautious about the precedent it sets to increase taxes on certain products in the name of "good." It seems dangerous to me for governments to decide which products should have higher taxes based on what is deemed "bad" for society. I don't wanna pay a high tax on video games even though it might be shown that they can be addictive and have a detrimental effect on mental or physical health. I like video games, it's my choice to play them. The free market should decide what I pay and I shouldn't be burdened with added cost because the government wants to deter me from playing them (Protip: they actually wouldn't want me to stop, because they'd be collecting a lot of money).

That's the real issue. It's that the way healthcare in America works, we end up paying for other people's medical expenses. It should be the person who chooses to smoke that pays the extra healthcare costs, not everyone else.

I absolutely despise smoking. My parents smoke and as a kid I always despised it. But raising taxes on them doesn't prevent smoking. If people were logical about it they wouldn't smoke because it's horrible for you and because it costs a lot of money to have that habit. People will make their own choices.

I'll concede to that.

It's not the same thing at all. I'm not saying you need to put in every single assumption, I'm saying to write down what's mathematically correct because it's correct and because it's good practice. I'm arguing that in math, these simple mistakes matter a lot more than they do in grammar.

integral[(dy/dx)ds]
has a completely different meaning than
integral[dy/dx]
Say there's a relationship between s, x and y. You can't do anything with the second one but the first one you can.
Edit: actually this would be a better example
integral[xy^3]
where x and y have a relationship. How do you know how to integrate this without the dx or dy?
I was stressing that it does make a difference to not put the dx, because the integral doesn't make mathematical sense. It's like putting a square root symbol with nothing inside it.
LOL
If you don't put the dx on an integral it doesn't make sense though. Yeah you can still compute things with mistakes like that but it's bad practice to not write things correctly.
There is nothing trivial in math though. A simple mistake means the whole thing is wrong.

WRITING.TITLE: Link might have the Master Sword, but Pikango has the Master Brush

WRITING.TEXT: What color Rito gear? I did orange because it looks like Luke Skywalker when he's in his orange jumpsuit.

All Barbarian gear fully upgraded. Weapon: savage lynel crusher. Shield: savage lynel shield. Bow: Savage lynel bow. If I break my lynel crusher i switch to a royal greatsword and if my shield breaks, royal shield. I never run out of lynel bows but sometimes I'll use a falcon bow or my great eagle bow when i'm firing from mid air.
